channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Claims Bakhmut Battle Is Wagner’s ‘Last Stand’
item.description: Ukrainians say Russia’s Wagner mercenary group is running low on fighters recruited from prisons, used in attacks on Bakhmut, where Ukraine has also endured heavy losses.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Servicemen from the 3rd Brigade mortar unit fire at Russian forces to support Ukrainian infantry near Bakhmut, on Tuesday.

item.title: Spying by Mexico’s Armed Forces Brings Fears of a ‘Military State’
item.description: This is the first time a paper trail has emerged to prove definitively that the Mexican military spied on citizens who were trying to expose its misdeeds.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times

item.title: France’s Fight Over Retirement Is a Question of Identity
item.description: Resistance to the government’s plan to push back the retirement age is not just about working longer. It springs from a deep sense of what defines France as a nation.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Martine Mirville, 67, with her granddaughters Ema and Julia in Granville, France, in February. “This is the time to enjoy life,” she said.

item.title: Unions Vow to Bring France to a ‘Standstill’ Over Macron’s Pension Plan
item.description: Travel, schools and services were disrupted by nationwide strikes and protests for a sixth time as the battle over the retirement age intensified.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Francois Lo Presti/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A rally in Dunkirk, northern France, on Tuesday as part of nationwide strikes to protest President Emmanuel Macron’s plans to raise the retirement age to 64 from 62.

item.title: 2 Americans Found Dead; 2 Found Alive in Mexico Kidnapping
item.description: Four friends crossed the border on Friday, but within hours, they were abducted by gunmen and two of them were killed before the others were rescued Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Maria Abi-Habib, Jack Nicas and Jacey Fortin
item.media:description: The scene where gunmen kidnapped four U.S. citizens in Matamoros, Mexico.

item.title: Secret Talks Seek Compromise Over Netanyahu’s Judicial Plans
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu’s plans to restrict judicial independence have divided Israel. But a small group of academics has met privately with lawmakers in a search for middle ground.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: A demonstration in Jerusalem on Saturday against the Israeli government’s proposed judicial overhaul.

item.title: 6 Palestinians Killed in Israeli Raid in West Bank
item.description: The Israeli military said one of those killed was suspected in the fatal shooting of two Israeli brothers in the West Bank village of Huwara, which set off revenge attacks by Jewish settlers.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Israeli army vehicles in the Jenin refugee camp in the northern West Bank during a raid on Tuesday.

item.title: Why Xi Jinping Blames U.S. Containment for China’s Troubles
item.description: Xi Jinping criticized what he called a U.S.-led campaign of “encirclement and suppression.” His new foreign minister said it was impossible for China not to fight back.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, at the opening of a meeting of the top legislature in Beijing on Sunday. He has held China up as a model that offers a different path to prosperity that rejects liberal democracy.

item.title: Outraged Over Illnesses Among Schoolgirls, Iranians Return to Streets
item.description: With thousands of girls falling ill and claims of poisonings, Iranians held the first wide-scale protests in months.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: A photo from social media purporting to show protesters outside an Education Ministry building in Tehran.

item.title: He Heeded Russia’s Call to Enlist. Five Months Later, He Was Dead.
item.description: Pvt. Ivan Ovlashenko was one of at least 16,000 Russians who have died in Ukraine, more than in the Soviets’ Afghan war. It’s getting hard for the Kremlin to cover that up.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva

item.title: U.S. Defense Secretary Affirms Support for Iraq on Baghdad Visit
item.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III met senior Iraqi officials less than two weeks before the 20th anniversary of the U.S.-led invasion of Iraq.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III on Tuesday in Erbil, Iraq.

item.title: New Japanese Rocket Is Destroyed During First Test Flight to Space
item.description: The H3 is intended to serve as the country’s flagship vehicle for sending satellites to orbit and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Michael Roston, Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: The H3 rocket, carrying a land observation satellite, lifting off at Tanegashima Space Center in southern Japan on Tuesday.

item.title: U.K. Plans to Expel Asylum Seekers Arriving on Small Boats
item.description: The proposal from the Conservative government particularly targets those arriving by irregular means across the English Channel, most of whom are asylum seekers fleeing war and persecution.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Migrants being escorted ashore in Dover, southern England, by British border officers after having been picked up at sea in March.

item.title: Fire in Bangladesh Camp Adds to Rohingya Refugees’ Misery
item.description: Twelve thousand residents of the camp, already some of the most dispossessed people on earth, were left without shelter.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Alex Travelli

item.title: Ukraine Needs Shells, and Arms Makers Want Money. Enter the E.U.
item.description: Ukraine is firing artillery shells faster than manufacturers can make them. Brussels is working on a plan to increase production by guaranteeing big advance purchases.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in Toretsk, Ukraine, on Tuesday. The country is going through shells faster than the West can produce or supply them.

item.title: In Western Ukraine, Far From the Battlefield but Not the War
item.description: It has been more than a year since Russia invaded Ukraine, and life continues on. Babies are born. Children go to school. Some families go skiing. And a reporter is paying attention.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians have found respite at ski mountains in the country’s west, including at the Bukovel resort in Polyanytsya.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: High Russian casualties in Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Servicemen from the 3rd Brigade mortar unit fire at Russian forces to support Ukrainian infantry near Bakhmut, on Tuesday.

item.title: Cuba Allows Some Major Leaguers on World Baseball Classic Team
item.description: For the first time, Cuba will allow some M.L.B. players to represent the team internationally. But many of the country’s biggest stars were left out, or declined their invitations.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:description: Yoán Moncada, an outfielder for the Chicago White Sox, and Andy Ibáñez, a minor leaguer in the Detroit Tigers system, are both representing Cuba at the World Baseball Classic.

item.title: Yuriy Lutsenko, Who Played a Key role in Trump’s First Impeachment, Loses His Military Command
item.description: Yuriy Lutsenko’s assignment as the commander of a platoon of drone operators near the embattled city of Bakhmut was short lived.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukraine’s former chief prosecutor, Yuriy Lutsenko, in 2019.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Xi Accuses the U.S. of ‘Suppression’
item.description: Also, the U.S. central bank may raise interest rates higher than expected.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Delegates applauded as Chinese President Xi Jinping, left, arrived for the opening session of China’s National People’s Congress (NPC) in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: Biden to Host South Korean President for State Visit in April
item.description: The fact that President Yoon Suk Yeol received the second such invitation of the Biden presidency speaks to the degree of cooperation expected from him on issues involving North Korea and China.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: President Biden and President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea have met several times in recent months.

item.title: Senator Whitehouse Puts Climate Change on Budget Committee’s Agenda
item.description: For more than a decade, Senator Sheldon Whitehouse gave daily warnings about the mounting threat of climate change. Now he has a powerful new perch.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Sheldon Whitehouse of Rhode Island chaired his first meeting of the Senate Budget Committee on Feb. 15, hoping to inject climate change into the heart of the partisan fight over federal spending.

item.title: Duong Tuong, Who Opened Western Works to Vietnamese Readers, Dies at 90
item.description: He translated works by Proust, Nabokov, Tolstoy and Emily Brontë into Vietnamese, and a classic Vietnamese poem, ‘The Tale of Kieu,’ into English.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans

item.title: Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant Conditions Have Deteriorated, Ukraine Says
item.description: The International Atomic Energy Agency last week warned that the situation at the plant, which Moscow seized soon after its invasion in February, was “precarious.”
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukraine says the condition of the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, which has six reactors on the Dnipro River, has deteriorated over the last year.

item.title: Intelligence Suggests Pro-Ukrainian Group Sabotaged Pipelines, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: New intelligence reporting amounts to the first significant known lead about who was responsible for the attack on the Nord Stream pipelines that carried natural gas from Russia to Europe.
item.dc:creator: Adam Entous, Julian E. Barnes and Adam Goldman
item.media:description: The Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in Lubmin, Germany, last year.

item.title: The Second Year of Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine, in Photos
item.description: Photographers in and around Ukraine have chronicled the devastation and misery wrought by the war.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier from the 79th Air Assault Brigade fighting Russian forces from a trench in the contested area of Marinka in eastern Ukraine on Feb. 26. This position was not far from Russian forces.

item.title: Ex-Minister Matt Hancock’s Leaked Texts Lift the Veil on U.K. Covid Policy
item.description: A trove of more than 100,000 WhatsApp messages exchanged between Matt Hancock, then the British health secretary, and other government figures revealed the scramble to coordinate the virus response.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Matt Hancock, then the British health secretary, in London in 2021. He said that the newspaper releasing the messages had published them selectively to push a narrative that the government overreacted with lockdowns.

item.title: A Real-life Spy Story
item.description: How the downfall of one intelligence agent revealed the astonishing reach of Chinese espionage.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: A Russian Editor Evades Putin’s Censorship
item.description: Galina Timchenko, founder of the dissident news site Meduza, has adapted as the information noose has tightened since the invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Alison Smale
item.media:description: Galina Timchenko, center, chief executive of the alternative news site Meduza, outside a Moscow court building in 2019. She was waiting for the appearance of an investigative journalist, Ivan Golunov.

item.title: An Architect Applies Her Skills to Giving Back
item.description: Diana Kellogg specialized in high-end New York residences. Now, she has designed a girls school in India and is pursuing other projects that address social change.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora

item.title: Moldova’s Pro-Europe Leader Tries to Thwart Russia’s Influence
item.description: Maia Sandu, president of the former Soviet republic, remains popular in a deeply divided nation as Vladimir V. Putin continues to apply pressure.
item.dc:creator: Celestine Bohlen
item.media:description: President Maia Sandu of Moldova, a former Soviet republic, last month in the capital, Chisnau. She is entering her third year as president.

item.title: Forging Connections Among Members of the African Diaspora
item.description: Almaz Negash lives in California, but never forgot her native Eritrea. Now she heads a group that brings together dispersed Africans, philanthropists, entrepreneurs and business leaders.
item.dc:creator: Eilene Zimmerman

item.title: A Pakistani Aid Worker Responds to Her Country’s Dire Needs
item.description: Dealing with refugees and record flooding, Shabnam Baloch is leading efforts in Pakistan for the International Rescue Committee.
item.dc:creator: Claudia Dreifus

item.title: Could the Next Blockbuster Drug Be Lab-Rat Free?
item.description: Alternatives to animal testing are gaining momentum.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:description: Last year, Congress passed a law allowing drug makers to collect safety and efficacy data using high-tech new tools, including bioengineered organs, organs on chips and computer models, instead of live animals.

item.title: Zelensky says Ukrainian troops won’t withdraw from Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in position with a howitzer in the Donbas region on Sunday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The next phase of protests in Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Military reservists protesting in Israel last month.

item.title: 4 Americans Kidnapped in Mexico Border City Were There Seeking Health Care
item.description: The four came under fire shortly after entering the city of Matamoros from Brownsville, Texas. The F.B.I. is offering a $50,000 reward for their return and the arrest of the kidnappers.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Amy soldiers during a search for four Americans who were kidnapped by gunmen last week, in Matamoros, Mexico, on Monday.

item.title: Ukraine Signals It Will Keep Battling for Bakhmut to Drain Russia
item.description: Gradual Russian advances and high Ukrainian casualties have fueled talk of a retreat from the eastern city, but Ukrainians say Russian losses are worse, a reason to keep them fighting.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on a tank headed in the direction of the frontline near Bakhmut this month.

item.title: Ukraine Opens Investigation Into Video of Ukrainian Soldier’s Execution
item.description: Ukrainian officials said they had opened a war crimes investigation.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential press service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: South Korea’s Olive Branch to Japan
item.description: Also, Ukraine says it wants to strengthen its presence in Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: A rally in Seoul on Monday denouncing the South Korean government’s proposal.

item.title: Protests Over Netanyahu’s Judiciary Overhaul Spread to Israel’s Military
item.description: The military leadership is concerned that anger over the government’s plan, with some pilots saying they will skip some training sessions and operations, could diminish military capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Israeli military reservists demonstrating near Jerusalem in February against proposed judicial changes by Israel’s right-wing government.

item.title: Iran’s Rulers, Shaken by Protests, Now Face Currency Crisis
item.description: Years of Western sanctions are partly to blame for the crisis. But economists say poor management by the country’s authoritarian clerical rulers also plays a big part.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iran, its residents often say, should be a rich country, with some of the world’s largest oil reserves and a well-educated population.

item.title: A Rival for Erdogan Emerges as Opposition Parties Pick a Candidate
item.description: Kemal Kilicdaroglu, the head of Turkey’s largest opposition party, and his allies are looking to unseat President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who they say has damaged the country’s democracy.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
item.media:description: Kemal Kilicdaroglu, the opposition’s presidential rival to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, addressing Parliament in December.

item.title: U.S. to Challenge Mexican Ban on Genetically Modified Corn
item.description: The Biden administration said it would request talks with Mexico over a brewing trade fight.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Linda Qiu
item.media:description: Mexico bought more than 20 million metric tons of corn from the United States in 2021-22, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Farmers in Mexico grew 27.3 million metric tons last year.

item.title: Belarus Sentences Exiled Opposition Leader to 15 Years in Prison
item.description: Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya fled the country after running for president in 2020 against Belarus’s authoritarian leader. She has described the conspiracy case against her as a “farce.”
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Belarusian exiled opposition leader, Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya, in Davos, Switzerland, in January.

item.title: How the Czech Republic Qualified for the World Baseball Classic
item.description: The World Baseball Classic is a battle of the game’s top professional players. A scrappy Czech Republic team, full of guys with regular jobs, just might win your heart.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein and Nina Riggio
item.media:description: Martin Schneider, 37, is a firefighter who moonlights as a top pitcher for the Czech Republic national team.

item.title: Asian Americans, Shifting Right
item.description: The new politics of class in America.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times

item.title: Ukraine Claims a Drone Strike on Military Target in Russia
item.description: The claim was a rare public acknowledgment of a cross-border attack in Russian territory.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A sign beside a road marking the boundary of the Bryansk region of Russia, which borders Ukraine.

item.title: Dalit Journalist Takes On India’s Caste Injustices
item.description: Meena Kotwal started a news outlet focused on Dalit and other marginalized groups in India, hoping that telling their stories would help improve their lives.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Meena Kotwal, the founder of The Mooknayak, at the news outlet’s office in New Delhi.

item.title: Maryse Condé, at Home in the World
item.description: Throughout her four-decade literary career, the Guadeloupean writer has explored a global vision of the Black diaspora, and placed Caribbean life at the center.
item.dc:creator: Anderson Tepper
item.media:credit: Violette Franchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maryse Condé has called writing a “force she can’t resist.” At 86, she still feels its powerful compulsion.

item.title: Estonia Election Delivers Vote of Confidence for Ukraine Aid
item.description: The party of Prime Minister Kaja Kallas, who has pushed the West to send more weapons to Kyiv and impose tougher penalties on Moscow, took about double the tally of the second-place finisher.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Prime Minister Kaja Kallas watching preliminary election results arrive in Tallinn, Estonia, on Sunday. She said the outcome provided a “strong mandate” to continue aiding Ukraine.

item.title: Ukrainian Soldiers, Nearly Encircled in Bakhmut, Push Russians Back
item.description: The battle for Bakhmut is not over — at least not yet. Ukrainian assault brigades offered Moscow a bloody reminder of that over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing artillery rounds toward a Russian infantry position near Bakhmut on Friday.

item.title: The West is scrambling to find Soviet-era weapons for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Justin Scheck, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Boryana Dzhambazova
item.media:credit: Nikolay Doychinov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The small mountain town of Kostenets, Bulgaria, will soon start producing shells for Soviet-era artillery for use by Ukraine’s military.

item.title: Ukraine’s helicopter brigades defy odds to remain operational.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak

item.title: Food security, energy and military aid: What to watch for this week.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Smoke rising from a Ukrainian position that was damaged on Friday by a Russian strike near Bakhmut.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: The fight for the Ukrainian city of Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Ukrainian howitzer firing a shell toward Bakhmut.

item.title: Historical Disputes Kept Them at Odds. Can Seoul and Tokyo Make Amends?
item.description: Icy relations between the two have long been a headache for Washington. South Korea made a significant step in improving ties this week, perhaps indicating progress to come.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A rally in Seoul on Monday denouncing the South Korean government’s proposal.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: China’s Post-Covid Economic Goal
item.description: Also, Russia tries to cut off Bakhmut, and countries reach an ocean biodiversity deal.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: A screen showing Chinese President Xi Jinping during the opening of the First Session of the 14th CPPCC National Committee in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: What Trench Warfare on Ukraine’s Front Line Looks Like
item.description: The Ukrainian military calls it the zero position, where Russian soldiers are close enough to see, and where an old war tactic takes a horrific toll.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Hicks and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Boghdan, a Ukrainian soldier, firing a rocket-propelled grenade toward Russian forces from a trench in an area of Marinka, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: The Story of Multicultural Canada, Told in Humble Strip Mall Eateries
item.description: Some of Toronto’s best dining options are mom-and-pop shops little known beyond their immigrant patrons, offering dishes that recall tastes from home or fuse new flavors together.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Tara Walton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Curry laksa at One2Snacks, a Malaysian takeout restaurant in the Dynasty Centre, a strip mall in Toronto.
